references: TableÂ I shows the comparison between the existing concurrent 3D VQA datasetsÂ [13, 14, 12] and our newly collected FE-3DGQA and the Ext. FE-3DGQA datasets. It can be seen that our FE-3DGQA dataset is the largest manually annotated 3D VQA dataset, with complete grounded object annotations. Moreover, by using additional template-based QAs, our Ext. FE-3DGQA dataset is the largest 3D VQA dataset.

To enrich our FE-3DGQA dataset, we further extend our 3D VQA dataset by transforming the original ScanNetÂ [15] dataset, the ScanReferÂ [8] dataset, and the Referit3DÂ [16] dataset into their QA-like versions based on the fixed templates for better scene understanding.
The statistics of the extended FE-3DGQA dataset are shown in Tab.Â II.
Below we describe how we transform each dataset into our Ext. FE-3DGQA in detail.

references:
In TableÂ III, we report the completely grounded 3D visual question answering (VQA) results including not only the QA results, but also the grounding results from three different types of objects. According to different types of answers, we split the validation set into 4 sub-classes: â€œnumberâ€, â€œcolorâ€, â€œyes/noâ€, and â€œotherâ€.
Since most recent methods and datasets are not open-sourced yet, we compare the results of our method with few state-of-the-art methodsÂ [13, 12] based on our implementation.
For fair comparison, we also add a grounding head to their methods and also report the grounding results of the three types of objects.
Note that we do not report the results of TransVQA3DÂ [14] since this baseline method requires additional relation graph annotations.

In general, all the 3D VQA methods outperform the pure QA results without the visual data (i.e., the results from random guess or the language priors), and our method achieves the best overall QA results, as well as the grounding results for all types of objects.
Specifically, our method achieves around 1.931.931.93% improvements in the â€œoverallâ€ QA results when compared with the recent 3DQA-TRÂ [13] method on the validation set.
For the grounding results, our method achieves remarkable performance gain of 8.828.828.82% in terms of the mAP@@@0.5 when compared with the ScanQAÂ [12] method.
We also compare our method with the methods using multiview 2D images with various vision-language fusion methods (i.e., MCANÂ [47] or pretrained T5 + co-attention). We found that the method using multiview images performs better for the â€œcolorâ€ subset, but worse for the â€œyes/noâ€ and â€œotherâ€ subsets, which requires 3D scene understanding.
The results show that our newly proposed method could effectively ground to the answer related objects and thus predict more accurate answers.
For the baseline methods ScanQAÂ [12] and 3DQA-TR from 3DQAÂ [13], the grounding results are poor, which indicate that their methods could not ground to the answer related objects precisely and thus are not well explainable.
We also conduct the experiments by combining the manually annotated dataset (i.e., FE-3DGQA) and the extended dataset (i.e., Ext. FE-3DGQA) in the training stage to further enhance our performance (see the 5th row in Table.Â III) for the 3D VQA task. We examine human performance by asking 4 human subjects to answer 400 randomly selected questions and identify the three types of related objects in the 3D scene. The average results are shown in the last row of Table.Â III. It can be seen that the performance gaps between all the algorithms and human are still large, which allows further exploitation of the 3D GQA task by using our dataset.
As shown in Table.Â IV, we also report the results of our methods on the ScanQAÂ [12] dataset.
Results show that our method outperforms the baseline methods.

We argue that the visually grounded results are more reliable and explainable. Here, we compare the QA results between our alternative method
called â€œOurs (w/o Grounding)â€
without considering the grounding task (i.e., â€œ Ldetection+0.5â€‹LQAsubscriptğ¿detection0.5subscriptğ¿QAL_{\text{detection}}+0.5L_{\text{QA}}â€) and our complete method based on the joint QA and grounding training strategy (i.e., â€œLAllsubscriptğ¿AllL_{\text{All}}â€).
As shown in Lines 3 and 4 of TableÂ V, we can see that the grounding results not only provide potential explanation capability to the QA results, but also improve the overall QA results to a certain degree. Moreover, with the additional detection loss Ldetectionsubscriptğ¿detectionL_{\text{detection}} from the vision branch, our alternative method â€œOurs (w/o Grounding)â€ (i.e., with 45.99% Acc.) also outperforms the â€œQA w/o Sceneâ€ method (i.e., â€œ LQAsubscriptğ¿QAL_{\text{QA}}â€, with 37.25% Acc. as shown in Line 1 of TableÂ III) by 8.74%, which also verifies that our 3D vision branch and the fusion method can significantly improve the 3D VQA results.

In general, all the 3D VQA methods outperform the pure QA results without the visual data (i.e., the results from random guess or the language priors), and our method achieves the best overall QA results, as well as the grounding results for all types of objects.
Specifically, our method achieves around 1.931.931.93% improvements in the â€œoverallâ€ QA results when compared with the recent 3DQA-TRÂ [13] method on the validation set.
For the grounding results, our method achieves remarkable performance gain of 8.828.828.82% in terms of the mAP@@@0.5 when compared with the ScanQAÂ [12] method.
We also compare our method with the methods using multiview 2D images with various vision-language fusion methods (i.e., MCANÂ [47] or pretrained T5 + co-attention). We found that the method using multiview images performs better for the â€œcolorâ€ subset, but worse for the â€œyes/noâ€ and â€œotherâ€ subsets, which requires 3D scene understanding.
The results show that our newly proposed method could effectively ground to the answer related objects and thus predict more accurate answers.
For the baseline methods ScanQAÂ [12] and 3DQA-TR from 3DQAÂ [13], the grounding results are poor, which indicate that their methods could not ground to the answer related objects precisely and thus are not well explainable.
We also conduct the experiments by combining the manually annotated dataset (i.e., FE-3DGQA) and the extended dataset (i.e., Ext. FE-3DGQA) in the training stage to further enhance our performance (see the 5th row in Table.Â III) for the 3D VQA task. We examine human performance by asking 4 human subjects to answer 400 randomly selected questions and identify the three types of related objects in the 3D scene. The average results are shown in the last row of Table.Â III. It can be seen that the performance gaps between all the algorithms and human are still large, which allows further exploitation of the 3D GQA task by using our dataset.
As shown in Table.Â IV, we also report the results of our methods on the ScanQAÂ [12] dataset.
Results show that our method outperforms the baseline methods.

We argue that the visually grounded results are more reliable and explainable. Here, we compare the QA results between our alternative method
called â€œOurs (w/o Grounding)â€
without considering the grounding task (i.e., â€œ Ldetection+0.5â€‹LQAsubscriptğ¿detection0.5subscriptğ¿QAL_{\text{detection}}+0.5L_{\text{QA}}â€) and our complete method based on the joint QA and grounding training strategy (i.e., â€œLAllsubscriptğ¿AllL_{\text{All}}â€).
As shown in Lines 3 and 4 of TableÂ V, we can see that the grounding results not only provide potential explanation capability to the QA results, but also improve the overall QA results to a certain degree. Moreover, with the additional detection loss Ldetectionsubscriptğ¿detectionL_{\text{detection}} from the vision branch, our alternative method â€œOurs (w/o Grounding)â€ (i.e., with 45.99% Acc.) also outperforms the â€œQA w/o Sceneâ€ method (i.e., â€œ LQAsubscriptğ¿QAL_{\text{QA}}â€, with 37.25% Acc. as shown in Line 1 of TableÂ III) by 8.74%, which also verifies that our 3D vision branch and the fusion method can significantly improve the 3D VQA results.

In Lines 2 and 4 of TableÂ V, we report the results by using different language modules (e.g., randomly initialized Bi-GRU and pre-trained T5). When compared to the randomly initialized Bi-GRU, our method using the pre-trained T5 language module achieves much better QA results as well as the grounding results. The results verify that our newly collected dataset contains more free-form questions. Without the pre-trained language module, the model is more prone to overfit to the questions and ground to the wrong objects due to insufficient language modeling capability in the Bi-GRU method, leading to poor QA results.

As discussed in Sec.Â V-B, we propose an enhanced self-attention module in the 3D vision branch to extensively encode the within-object features and across-object spatial distances to help the model attend and ground to all the answer related objects.
In Lines 1 and 4 of TableÂ V, we compare the results of our method and the alternative method that uses the standard self-attention modules. We can see that the enhanced self-attention module contributes to both the final QA results and the grounding results.
Specifically, the grounding results of the â€œAG-NotIn-Qâ€ objects (i.e., the answer-grounded objects not appeared in the question) are improved by 2.7%,
which verifies that a good visual encoding module helps us identify the challenging but essential â€œAG-NotIn-Qâ€ objects.

In Tab.Â VI, we report the grounded visual question answering results of our newly proposed method based on the test set of our newly collected FE-3DGQA dataset together with different extended training datasets.
In this table, â€œmanualâ€ means our original manually annotated FE-3DGQA dataset, â€œdet.â€ represents the transformed 3D detection dataset (i.e., ScanNet), â€œground.â€ represents the transformed 3D visual grounding datasets (i.e., ScanRefer and Nr3D), and â€œExt.â€ represents the full extended FE-3DGQA dataset, which consists of the transformed detection dataset, the transformed visual grounding dataset, and the transformed masked visual grounding dataset.
Note that as the annotations of the related objects for the samples from both the transformed 3D grounding datasets and the transformed masked 3D grounding datasets are incomplete,
we remove the corresponding loss functions for â€œAG-NotIn-Qâ€ and â€œContext-Of-AGâ€ (resp. â€œAG-In-Qâ€ and â€œContext-Of-AGâ€) in the object type classification loss Ltâ€‹yâ€‹pâ€‹esubscriptğ¿ğ‘¡ğ‘¦ğ‘ğ‘’L_{type} for the vision branch, and the semantic label and type classification loss Lsâ€‹eâ€‹mâˆ’câ€‹lâ€‹ssubscriptğ¿ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ L_{sem-cls} of the language branch for the samples from the transformed 3D grounding datasets (resp. the transformed masked 3D grounding datasets).
